the_6_Ps_of_ischemia.Pain: Out of proportion to visible injury, worsens with passive stretch
the_6_Ps_of_ischemia.Pallor: Pale or mottled skin compared to contralateral limb
the_6_Ps_of_ischemia.Pulselessness: Absent palpable pulses distal to injury

clinical_significance.delay_consequences: Every hour of delay increases amputation risk

upper_extremity: Axillary: Absent brachial/radial pulses, axillary hematoma
Brachial: Absent radial pulse, antecubital hematoma
Forearm: Absent radial/ulnar pulses, forearm hematoma
lower_extremity: Femoral: Absent popliteal/pedal pulses, groin hematoma
Popliteal: Absent pedal pulses, popliteal hematoma
Tibial: Absent pedal pulses, calf hematoma

immediate_actions: Establish IV access, type and crossmatch
do_NOT: Transfer to distant facility if operative capability exists

soft_signs: History of arterial bleeding at scene (now controlled)
Injury in proximity to major vessel
comparison_soft_signs.soft_sign_management: Imaging (CTA, angiography, or duplex) to clarify diagnosis

timely_intervention.amputation_rate: Increases significantly after 6-8 hours of warm ischemia

definition.@value: Physical findings indicating >90% probability of significant arterial injury requiring immediate surgical exploration without preoperative imaging

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define and list the hard signs of vascular injury
Distinguish hard signs from soft signs
Understand the high positive predictive value of hard signs
Recognize that hard signs mandate immediate operative exploration
Apply the 6 Ps of ischemia assessment
clinical_pearls: Hard signs = OR, no imaging needed
Pulsatile hemorrhage and expanding hematoma are the most specific hard signs
The 6 Ps progress in order: Pain → Pallor → Pulselessness → Paresthesias → Paralysis → Poikilothermia
Paralysis is a late and ominous finding indicating advanced ischemia
